messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: The most skilled
messages.msgSnippet: ... Bah! That s nothing! Nitta Yoshisada (1301 - 1338) managed to cut off his own head and bury it! Even if one s head were to be suddenly cut off, he should
messages.messageBody:
> LOL--it would take skill to cut off your own head,
> wouldn't it?

Bah! That's nothing! Nitta Yoshisada (1301 - 1338) managed to cut off his own head and bury it!

"Even if one's head were to be suddenly cut off, he should be able to do one more action with certainty. The last moments of Nitta Yoshisada are proof of this. Had his spirit been weak, he would have have fallen the moment his head was severed."
Hagakure

A curiousity - especially as he was attending a family BBQ at the time ... no, that's a fib, but imagine! ("Mum! Dad's buried his head again!")

Thomas

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] The most skilled
messages.msgSnippet: How about Kusunoki Masahige?  He is always portrayed as a martial paragon in the chronicles. Ijin Mibu  wrote:  I was wandering who poeple
messages.messageBody:
How about Kusunoki Masahige? He is always portrayed as a martial paragon in the chronicles.

Ijin Mibu <ijinmibu@...> wrote: I was wandering who poeple is the mosted skilled swordsman. And if
someone says Musashi I'll cut you up!

Maikeru
